title: Central Deafness Secondary to Herpes Encephalitis
chief_complaint: I can read and write, but I cannot understand what people are saying to me. I don't recognize my family's voices.

problem_summary.onset: Acute onset at age 13 following severe illness diagnosed as herpes encephalitis.
problem_summary.course: Initial total lack of auditory responsiveness. Over months/years, sound detection sensitivity improved significantly, but speech understanding remained profoundly impaired (pure word deafness profile).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Headaches, numbness, seizures, behavioral changes (impulsivity), left eye ptosis, alternating exotropia, loss of speech intonation.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Cannot understand spoken speech; relies on speechreading, gestures, and writing. Doing well in math and reading at school.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Motivation fluctuates with depression; goal is to use environmental cues and plasticity to regain auditory processing.

history.present_illness: Admitted with fever (40°C), vomiting, right-sided facial twitching, and nonsensical talk. Diagnosed with herpes encephalitis.
history.medical_psych_history: Previously a very good student. Developed increased intracranial pressure during illness.

tests.name: Behavioral Observation
tests.key_findings: Patient was auditorily unresponsive. No behavioral response to pure tone stimuli.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Reported as normal absolute and interwave intervals (waveforms not available to current clinic).

history.present_illness: Several months post-illness. Patient difficult to test due to behavior/upset.
history.medical_psych_history: Behaviors included spitting, throwing objects, impulsivity.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Profound hearing loss range for mid-frequencies. Low frequencies at high intensities yielded vibration responses only.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Contralateral reflexes present at normal levels (500-4000 Hz). Ipsilateral reflexes present normal (500-2000 Hz), absent at 4000 Hz.

history.present_illness: Patient referred for comprehensive neuroaudiologic evaluation approx 2 months after V2.
history.medical_psych_history: MRI shows extensive damage to right mid/posterior temporal lobe (Heschl's gyrus) and damage to left posterior temporal lobe.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Significant recovery of sensitivity. Right ear improved to WNL/mild loss. Left ear improved to mild/moderate loss. High frequency deficits persist, worse in Left ear.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Cannot understand speech (0% recognition implied), except for recognizing her name. Speech Detection Thresholds (SDT) are consistent with pure tones.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Normal absolute and interwave intervals bilaterally. Replicable responses down to low levels.

tests.name: Middle Latency Response (MLR)
tests.key_findings: Unable to obtain any repeatable responses for either ear or electrode site. Tracings are noisy due to anxiety.

tests.name: Late Auditory Evoked Potentials
tests.key_findings: No consistent responses for any electrode site or ear.

tests.name: Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE)
tests.key_findings: Essentially normal bilaterally. Indicates intact outer hair cells despite high-frequency pure tone deficits.

tests.name: Psychoacoustics (Difference Limens)
tests.key_findings: Extremely poor intensity and frequency discrimination.

numeric_results.Intensity DL (1kHz @ 70dB): Could not reach 50% performance for 5 dB increments

overall_audiologic_summary: This is a case of Central Deafness (or cortical deafness/auditory agnosia) resulting from herpes encephalitis with bilateral temporal lobe damage (Right > Left). Peripheral hearing mechanisms are intact, evidenced by normal OAEs, normal ABRs, and acoustic reflexes. However, cortical processing is absent (absent MLR/LLR) or severely impaired. While pure-tone detection sensitivity recovered significantly over 2 years, the patient exhibits 'pure word deafness' characteristics: she can detect sound (SDT 5-25 dB HL) but cannot discriminate speech or complex acoustic features (frequency DL > 200 Hz).
counseling_points: Explain that the 'ears' (cochlea) are working perfectly, but the brain's 'processing center' for sound was damaged by the infection.
Highlight that while sound detection has returned, the ability to distinguish *what* the sound is (speech vs. noise, pitch changes) is impaired.
Emphasize the importance of visual cues (speechreading, signing) and environmental context.
Discuss neuroplasticity: the brain is young and may reorganize, but active rehabilitation is required.
Manage expectations: hearing sensitivity may fluctuate with general health/fatigue.
notes_for_actor: You are not 'deaf' in the traditional sense. You hear the beeps clearly now, but speech sounds like garbled noise or a foreign language you don't know.
You are intelligent, literate, and can read/write perfectly. You are frustrated that you can't understand spoken words.
You may be anxious or jumpy during testing because sounds are confusing.
Your speech has lost its 'music' (intonation/prosody)—speak in a flatter, more monotonic way.
You rely heavily on watching the audiologist's face/lips to understand instructions.
